question_and_explanation:
<Question>
[A research team is investigating the effects of a novel synthetic agonist, "Compound X," on neuronal excitability in hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neurons. They observe that Compound X binding to a specific G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) located on these neurons results in a significant and sustained hyperpolarization of the membrane potential. Further investigation reveals that this hyperpolarization is accompanied by an increased potassium ion (K+) conductance, which is blocked by the selective GIRK channel antagonist, tertiapin.]
</Question>
<Options>
A. Compound X likely activates a GPCR coupled to Gαq, leading to increased intracellular calcium levels and subsequent GIRK channel activation.
B. Compound X likely activates a GPCR coupled to Gαs, leading to increased cAMP levels and direct phosphorylation of the GIRK channel.
C. Compound X likely activates a GPCR coupled to Gαi/o, leading to dissociation of Gβγ subunits, which directly bind to and open the GIRK channel.
D. Compound X likely activates a GPCR coupled to Gα12/13, leading to activation of Rho GTPases and downstream effects on actin polymerization, indirectly affecting GIRK channel activity.
</Options>

<Explanation>
... (trimmed for brevity) ...
</Explanation>
<Answer>:
C
</Answer>

<Question>
[Consider a rhythmic motor circuit controlling alternating flexor and extensor muscle activity...]
</Question>
<Options>
A. The CMs likely receive excitatory input...
B. The CMs are likely principal neurons...
C. The CMs likely form reciprocal inhibitory connections...
D. The CMs are likely sensory neurons...
</Options>

<Explanation>
... (trimmed for brevity) ...
</Explanation>
<Answer>:
C
</Answer>
